The car above is not unlike plenty of others whose drivers do what they can to avoid the large dip. The Chessie System railroad company plans to raise the sunken track at the crossing on Haggerty Road south of Joy. Project engineer Tom Tippie said the $5,000 job will begin sometime in August and take a week to complete. Haggerty Road will be closed to traffic at that point for the duration of the work, Tippie said. Motorists are advised to use Lil- ley Road as a detour during construction. Residents are expected to be advised of the exact date of construction as workers move their way up the tracks from Toledo as they complete projects along the way. Although the railroad line in question has existed since 1868, Tippie said, the crossing at Haggerty Road has existed just two years. The tracks formerly crossed Haggerty at a point about 250 feet northwest of the current location before the road was relocated. Tippie said. It's not uncommon for railroad tracks at new crossings to settle, Tippie said. The crossing has settled at least two inches, leaving an abrupt bump between tracks and concrete. "We are writing to ask that you take a'strong stand against the divisive politics of Deborah Whyman See WHYMAN, 2A Firefighters host softball benefit BY JOANNE MAUSZEWSKL STAFF WRITER If the success and popularity of the Canton firefighters' and police benefit hockey games are any clue, get ready for a rarin' good time at their benefit softball game Aug. 3. . The softball game - of a minimum seven innings - will pit Canton firefighters and police against a celebrity team of Detroit Red Wings. "There will be some participation by the (Red Wings) alumni and TV sportscasters from channels 50 and 4." said firefighter Mike Caruso. For example, sportscaster Eli Zaret will participate. The 7 p.m. game at Canton Softball Center on Michigan Avenue is the first charity event sponsored by the fire- fighters newly created charitable foundation. The purpose of the Canton Firefighters #2289 Charity Foundation is to raise money and distribute it to causes and organizations, such as Special Olympics, March of Dimes and muscular dystrophy. The foundation's four-member board of directors may also give money to residents who are severely injured in accidents or fires. "Any money brought to the foundation is dispersed to other charities," Caruso said. Proceeds from the Aug. 3 softball game will go to Special Olympics and the foundation. "In no way possible is the money to support our union or our firefighters," Caruso said. See FIREFIGHTERS, 10A New senior apartments coming to Canton BY RALPH R. ECHTINAW STAFF WRITER Officials broke ground Wednesday for the $4 million expansion of Canton Place, a 117-unit apartment house for low-income seniors. Work it expected to begin within two weeks on the six-story, 56-unit apartment building, which will rise next to the existing building on the MHithwest earner af Ford and Sheldon. Joe Dilorio of DeMaria Building Company of Novi expects construction to last about one year.
